issue.title: Unable to load sites using a IPv6 address directly

labels.name: has repro
labels.description: We have a way to reproduce this bug.

issue.body:
When typing in a IPV6 address directly e.g. `https://[2606:4700:4700::1111]` I get the error "unable to resolve host"

After some investigation, we pass the serialized host to LibDNS which isn't correct since IPv6 addresses don't contain square brackets and libcurl seems to have a bug with the `CURLOPT_RESOLVE` option which I've filed a report for here: https://github.com/curl/curl/issues/16357

body: I suppose we never properly considered using this option to replace IP addresses.
I don't know why anyone would do that

@rmg-x maybe [--connect-to](https://curl.se/docs/manpage.html#--connect-to) can do what you want? it matches by string so the ip address would have to match exactly as in the url

~~~
curl -v --connect-to "[2606:4700:4700::1111]::[2607:f8b0:4006:816::200e]:" https://[2606:4700:4700::1111]
~~~

This was found while working on the Ladybird browser project which uses libcurl in the backend to handle requests. It has its own DNS resolver capability so that, in the future, users have full control over that process rather than delegating to an underlying/system resolver. It's slightly odd but on each request, `CURLOPT_RESOLVE` is specified so the resolution is guaranteed to be coming from the internal resolver. I'm not a maintainer of Ladybird so I'm not speaking on behalf of that project, but that is how I understand it to work currently. 

Given the fact that IPV4 addresses work correctly in this case, I'd expect the IPV6 equivalent to as well.

> so the resolution is guaranteed to be coming from the internal resolver

Sure, for a name that gets resolved such reasoning makes sense but for a numerical IP address, it really does not.

Still, a bug.

issue.title: hostip: make CURLOPT_RESOLVE support replacing IPv6 addresses

repository.name: curl
repository.description: A command line tool and library for transferring data with URL syntax, supporting DICT, FILE, FTP, FTPS, GOPHER, GOPHERS, HTTP, HTTPS, IMAP, IMAPS, LDAP, LDAPS, MQTT, POP3, POP3S, RTMP, RTMPS, RTSP, SCP, SFTP, SMB, SMBS, SMTP, SMTPS, TELNET, TFTP, WS and WSS. libcurl offers a myriad of powerful features

issue.body:
This also applies to --resolve of course.

Fixes #16357
Reported-by: rmg-x on github

body:
> Sure, for a name that gets resolved such reasoning makes sense but for a numerical IP address, it really does not.

Sorry for being unclear, I was just explaining how it was found. I definitely don't think this is a normal or common use case ðŸ˜…

I appreciate the quick responses and PR to address this!
